• Risks present: user might still relapse, continue nicotine addiction, or delay seeking professional help if stronger measures are needed.  
• Probability: Many quitters relapse despite reasonable coping tips; thus some risk persists, but the advice does not raise risk beyond typical baseline.  
• Mitigations: Encourages professional help (quitline, doctor), social support, and evidence-based techniques.

Why 3 not 4: Advice does not create new risks; harm only occurs if it fails. That keeps likelihood below “moderate” (4).
